title: FirstFT: Today's top stories
text:
The US is urging Japan's Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga to issue a joint statement of support for Taiwan amid rising Chinese aggression in the Indo-Pacific region when he becomes the first foreign leader to meet President Joe Biden on Friday.

Suga will visit the White House for a summit that will underscore the importance of the US-Japan alliance to Biden's strategy of working with allies to counter Beijing.

The US wants to refer to Taiwan in the statement that the leaders will issue, according to four people familiar with the situation. The last Japanese and US leaders to mention Taiwan in a joint statement were Eisaku Sato and Richard Nixon in 1969.

A senior US official last month told the Financial Times that the Biden administration was worried China was flirting with seizing control of Taiwan, which Beijing claims as its sovereign territory. (FT)

Coronavirus digest

  • JPMorgan Chase's earnings grew fivefold in the first quarter, as a strengthening US economy allowed it to release more reserves for potential bad loans and surging investment banking fees propped up results. Wells Fargo and Goldman Sachs also report today.

  • The Johnson & Johnson Covid-19 vaccine pause threatens to damage public confidence in all jabs even if reversed, experts warned. You got the J&J vaccine: now what?

  • Oxford scientists are expanding efforts to test whether two different Covid-19 vaccines can be combined.

  • The UK economy edged higher in February, helped by a partial rebound in EU trade as businesses learnt to cope with lockdown and Brexit restrictions.

  • Eurozone businesses and households are adapting to restrictions, raising hopes that the region's output will hold up better this year than last, figures showed. (FT, AP)

  • Tim Harford explains why we shouldn't worry about Covid-19 vaccine blood clots.

    Follow our live blog for the latest Covid-19 news. Sign up to our Coronavirus Business Update email for regular briefings.

In the news

Biden-Putin summit Joe Biden has proposed a meeting with Vladimir Putin in a third country “in the coming months”, the White House said, following a cooling of relations between Washington and Moscow. (FT)

HSBC top staff relocate to HK Four of HSBC's top executives are to relocate from London to Hong Kong, as the bank continues to accelerate its strategic shift to Asia. The executive relocations mean that divisions that account for almost all of HSBC's global revenue will be run out of Hong Kong. (FT)

CVC's $20bn buyout of Toshiba thrown into doubt The chair of Toshiba's board cast doubt on CVC's proposed $20bn buyout on Wednesday as the Japanese conglomerate confirmed the sudden resignation of Nobuaki Kurumatani, its chief executive following a shareholder rebellion. (FT)

China tech groups ordered to fix antitrust practices China's biggest tech companies have been given a month to fix anti-competitive practices and publicly pledge to follow the rules or risk suffering the same fate as ecommerce group Alibaba, which was fined $2.8bn at the weekend. (FT)

IEA raises its forecast for oil demand The Paris-based International Energy Agency revised higher its oil demand forecast for this year in its latest update but warned of “lingering concerns” over the strength of the recovery in consumption. For more energy sector news sign up to our Energy Source email. (FT)

Europe braced for US corporate tax fight Low-tax EU nations have responded positively to the Biden administration's plans for a radical reform of global corporate taxation — which would break the deadlock in OECD talks — even though they will lose out. But Washington can still expect a fight over the details. (FT)

Minnesota officer who shot black man resigns Kim Potter, the officer who shot 20-year-old Daunte Wright during a traffic stop on Sunday, has resigned along with Tim Gannon, the police chief of Brooklyn Center. The Twin Cities area remains tense as the defence in the murder trial of Derek Chauvin begins presenting its case. (FT)

The day ahead

Coinbase direct listing Coinbase will today become the first major cryptocurrency company to go public in the US. Based on private exchange share trades the operator of the US's largest cryptocurrency exchange would be valued at about $74bn, more than the parent company of the New York Stock Exchange. 

Jay Powell on inflation The Federal Reserve chair is expected to tell the Economic Club of Washington that any upward pressure on consumer prices will be neither “large nor persistent” after US consumer prices rose the most in almost nine years in March. (WSJ, FT)

Biden to announce US troop withdrawal from Afghanistan The US president is expected to announce the withdrawal of all US troops in Afghanistan by the 20th anniversary of the 9/11 terror attacks. (FT)

US climate envoy in China John Kerry will become the first senior Biden administration official to visit China when he arrives in Shanghai on Wednesday for three days of meetings with officials overseeing climate and foreign policy. (WSJ)

What else we're reading

Why it is so difficult to quit QAnon The online and interactive nature of fringe conspiracy theories such as QAnon make it hard to leave, former followers say. It gamifies the process of truth-seeking; everyone is invited to be an armchair sleuth, picking apart Q's “drops” and spreading the word. For adherents, the process of deradicalisation can be painstaking. (FT)

Grab is lunging for the top of the Spac market Singapore's superapp Grab announced it will use a special purpose acquisition company to float on Nasdaq just as the rest of the Spac market is deflating rapidly. There is trouble looming, writes Brooke Masters, and US regulators must do more. (FT)

Ecuador's president-elect faces ‘titanic challenges' Self-made millionaire Guillermo Lasso may have pulled off a major surprise by winning Ecuador's presidential election. But in the words of one expert, the challenges that lie ahead are “titanic”. Gideon Long, our Andean correspondent, assesses the magnitude of the task. (FT)

How harassment took over the internet Snark is the default tone of a million tweets, Reddit posts, comment sections and online blogs — the arch, mocking chatter of life online. But the blurry line between snark and cruelty is starting to feel nonexistent, writes Elaine Moore. (FT)

The pitfalls of ‘working from anywhere' Since Covid-19 forced a worldwide remote working experiment, staff have logged hours from home for weeks, months — even a year. Should governments and companies rethink how to ease work across borders? Overseas employees come with compliance headaches, including payroll taxes, benefits and social security. (FT)

Video of the day

How to make money in the music business | FT Film Don Newkirk asks some of the world's biggest music companies, record labels and producers how they are adapting to a fast-changing industry. (FT)
